sub_topic: Determining the edge connectivity of a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph G with 12 vertices and 18 edges. Determine the minimum number of edges that need to be removed to disconnect the graph.
message_2:
To disconnect a graph, we need to remove enough edges such that there is no path between at least one pair of vertices. In other words, we want to create at least one isolated vertex.

A tree is a connected graph with no cycles and has exactly n-1 edges, where n is the number of vertices. In our case, a tree with 12 vertices would have 11 edges. Since G has 18 edges, it has 7 more edges than a tree with the same number of vertices.

To disconnect G, we can remove edges to create a tree and then remove one more edge to disconnect the tree. Therefore, we need to remove at least 7 edges (to make it a tree) + 1 edge (to disconnect the tree) = 8 edges. So, the minimum number of edges that need to be removed to disconnect the graph is 8.
